Sir:

I beg to state in further reference to the subject matter of your communications #130688-1 that Mr. Ray McInerney who has been teaching at "Big Cove" in Kent County, N.B., has decided not to continue as Teacher of that school, consequently another Teacher is now required.

I am herewith enclosing you, applications that I have received from enquiries made, as follows:

Miss Rosie A. Archibald, Cross Point, N.B. This is the same individual that formerly taught at Big Cove, previous to Mr. McInerney. I may say, that the Band does not approve of engaging her again for this position, although I consider her a good teacher.

Miss Janie Clary, Grand Gaspapedia, N.B. and Miss Harriet Keating, Strathadam, Northumberland County, N.B.

I have written to Miss Clary for testimonials, qualifications etc., and as soon as I receive them, I will forward them to the Department. In the meantime, you might kindly consider the enclosed applications and let me hear from you on the matter, as I would like to have a Teacher secured for the beginning of the term.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

The Secretary,
Your obedient servant,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Grand Cassapedia June 20th

Dear Sir,

Enclosed you will find a certificate of my character, from Rev. Peter Duffy, and signed by two of Newcastle's most noted men. Also a recommendation from my teacher, Miss Mary Adams.

I am eighteen years of age, though inexperienced, but should you appoint me to the position of teacher, for Big Cove School, I shall strive to discharge my duties earnestly and steadily, and
shall ever remain, your grateful and obedient servant.

Harriet E. Keating
To Whom It May Concern:

This is to certify that I have known Harriet Keating as a student in this school during the past year. She is a good student, attentive to her work, and well up in the subjects prescribed in the Course of Study for the N.B. Schools.

Although she has as yet had no professional training, I should consider her well qualified to take charge of one of your schools.

Yours Respectfully,

Mary Adams
(teacher)

Ottawa, August 14, 1911.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department was of opinion that you would have advised Miss Sutton of her appointment as teacher of the Big Cove School upon the receipt of official letter of the 26th ultimo. On the 4th instant Miss Sutton was communicated with and informed that the Department was pleased to know that she would take charge of the school after the summer holidays. Some other instructions with regard to the teaching of science, calisthenics and hygiene, etc., were given her.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. J. Ryan,
Supt. of Indian Schools,
St. Mary's Ferry, N.B.
NEW BRUNSWICK.

Northeastern Division,
Buctouche, September 18, 1911.

Sir:

I beg to state, that there are three white children living two distant from any white school to attend, that are desirous of attending the Indian School at Big Cove, which is quite near to them. Will you kindly advise me if they be permitted to attend and under what conditions.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, September 22, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, and in reply I beg to say that provided there is accommodation and that the teacher has no objection the three white children to whom you refer may be allowed to attend the Big Cove Indian School. A reasonable fee should, however, be exacted to be given to the teacher as remuneration for the extra work entailed. Be good enough to state what you consider would be a reasonable fee. These fees should be collected quarterly and handed over by you to the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.
Dalhousie, N.B.
Oct. 4, 1911

R.A. Irving Esq.,
Buctouche, N.B.

Dear Sir:

I am now in the employ of the Dalhousie Branch of the Royal Bank. I am getting along well and like the work. On July 1st last I wrote you a letter containing the returns of the Big Cone School. I stated that as I had taught 182 days and as I had only been paid $56.74 I should get the remainder of the salary. The days required by the Department to be taught were in number 316 and as I have had taught 182 days I should have been paid $52.77 for my year service. As I have already received $31.94 there is a balance of $20.83 due me. On teacher Ryan's visit to the school last spring I asked him if I should not receive more than $78 at the end of the year and he said that I would certainly get more as teachers were paid for the days that they taught. Hoping that you will consider my request.

Yours truly,

Ray McInerney
Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith a communication that I received from Mr. Ray McInerney, formerly teacher of the Big Cove Indian School, which will read for itself.

Mr. McInerney claims a balance of Twenty-one Dollars and Eighty-three cents due him for his services as said teacher.

Will you kindly advise me in reference to the matter.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant enclosing a communication from Ray McInerney, late teacher of the Big Cove Indian School, with reference to the amount of salary paid him for the period which he taught this school I beg to inform you that a cheque for $24.83, being the balance due, will be sent you.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant in which you ask for permission to expend the sum of $12.00 for each of the three schools in your Superintendency.

In reply I beg to say that the Department considers that the grant formerly allowed, $10.00, is a fair amount. You may, therefore, expend this sum for each of the schools and forward vouchers in the usual way.

Sir;—

I have the honour to report, that the Chief of Big Cove Band has applied to me for a new Teacher for the Big Cove Indian School. He claims that there is some dissatisfaction among the Indians with the present teacher and that they would like to have a teacher who could play the organ in the Church on Sunday during their services. I may say, that Miss Johnson of Richibucto, daughter of Sheriff B.J. Johnson, who holds no license to teach but who is well educated and who can play the organ, is willing to accept the position. In the event of a change. As the time is short, I would like to have as early a reply as possible in order that the school might open at the beginning of the present term, providing the change was made.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 17, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th inst., and in reply I beg to say that, in view of the favourable reports received on Miss Sutton's work at the Big Cove school, it is not the intention of the Department to replace her at present. The reasons advanced by the Indians are not considered sufficient.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

R. A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.
Sir;—

I have the honour to enclose herewith, Quarterly school return of Miss Kathelyn E.M. Sutton, Teacher of Big Cove Indian School, Kent County, N.B. for the quarter ended September 30th., last past, which I trust you will find satisfactory and correct.

I do recommend that Miss Sutton's salary be increased from $350.00 to $400.00 per year to commence from the First of July last past, the same as Miss Geraghty's salary, teacher of the Burnt Church Indian School. I consider that Miss Sutton is doing efficient work in her school and the average attendance is good and I think her efforts to increase education in this byand should be recognized. I therefor consider that as a reward for merit her salary should be increased to $400.00 per year.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary, Indian Superintendent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 14, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant in which you recommend an increase in salary from $300.00 to $400.00 for Miss Sutton, teacher of the Big Cove School.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the favourable reports received from yourself and Mr. Superintendent Ryan on Miss Sutton's work and the fact that there is a very fair enrolment and average attendance at this school, the Department will pay Miss Sutton at the rate of $400.00 per annum from the first of the current quarter.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Secretary.

R. A. Irvine, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Hootouchee, N.S.

Ottawa, February 28, 1913.

Sir,

Miss Sutton, teacher of the Big Cove Indian School, in her annual report states that she is convinced that better results would be obtained if a mid-day meal were served.

This has not been done in New Brunswick, but the Department would like to have a report from you as to the necessity of providing these children with a mid-day lunch. The usual practice is to furnish only a limited supply to supplement that brought by the children from home and give them a cup of tea and this practice is only followed when children come some distance to school and have to carry cold lunches. The Department would like to have your opinion on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R.A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Riotouche, N.B.
Sir;-

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the above number of the Twenty-eighth Ultimo regarding the matter of a mid day meal for the scholars of the Big Cove Indian School, and in reply I may say that I do not consider the same necessary and do not approve of the same as the children that attend this school live in the immediate vicinity of the school and very few, if any, bring their lunch to school for dinner hour, consequently, if you did provide them with anything you would have to provide them with a full meal and I feel that under the circumstances that this would be impracticable.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Ontario, March 13, 1912.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 8th instant, I am to say that the Department agrees with you that a mid-day meal for the scholars of the Big Cove Indian School is unnecessary.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Having been informed recently that the Big Cove Indian School would be vacant next term, I beg leave to offer you my services, trusting that you will favour me with an immediate reply and that you are always enjoying good health.

Yours very sincerely,

Natalie Batiste.
Sir:

I have the honour to report that some of the members of the Big Cove Indian Band would like to have another Teacher in lieu of the present teacher Miss Kathelyn E. M.Sutton, whose services as Teacher of this school are not very satisfactory, and I am today in receipt of an application from Miss Nathalie Babin for this school, which I herewith enclose. Miss Babin formerly taught in this school and also was teacher for considerable time of the Burnt Church Indian school. In the event of the Department making a change, it would be proper that Miss Sutton be notified as soon as possible, that her services will not be required after the Christmas holidays.

Kindly instruct me upon the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Superintendent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, November 17, 1913.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant stating that some of the members of the Big Cove Band would like to have another teacher to replace Miss Kathelyn E. M. Sutton and submitting an application from Miss Natalie Babain for the position, should a vacancy occur.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the favourable reports received from yourself and Mr. Superintendent Ryan on Miss Sutton's work, the Department is not disposed to dispense with her services at present. The Chief of the band is the truant officer and if he attends to his duties properly there should be no reason why the attendance should not be satisfactory and you will be good enough to so inform him.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.
Extract from report of Rev. J. J. Ryan, Superintendent of Indian Schools, on the Big Cove School, dated July 31, 1913. Original on 130688/6.

The attendance at this school is far from being up to the average of the other schools of the province and the reason seems to be the total indifference of the parents to the education of their children. Being ignorant themselves they fail to realize the importance of a little learning to their children and on the slightest pretext they keep them at home.

A few live at a distance, but that should be no obstacle to their attending school, as many of the white children throughout the provinces have much greater distances to cover to attend school.
Mundleville, N.B.
Nov. 13, 1913.

Mr. R.A. Irving,
Quintana, N.B. 437147

Dear Sir:

I applied for the Big Cove School last summer but learned afterwards that the teacher was not leaving.

I have heard quite lately that Miss Sutton was not going to teach there any longer than this term so I am sending in another application.

I attended the Provincial Normal School during the year ending June, 1913 and obtained a Second Class Licence.

I am teaching in Mundleville at present. Hoping to receive a favorable reply to this application.

I am,

Yours truly,

Alice McLaughlin.

I have the honour to enclose herewith an application from Miss Alice McLaughlin, for the Big Cove Indian School, Kent County, N.B. You will notice by reference to it, that Miss McLaughlin holds a second class teacher's license from the Normal school of this Province.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Superintendent Ryan writes the Department that Miss Sutton, present teacher of the Big Cove Indian School, Kent County, N.B., has sent in her resignation to take effect at the end of the present quarter.

There are two applications on file for this position, one from Miss Natalie Babain of Richibucto, who taught the Burnt Church School for two and a half years and resigned in April, 1910, and the other from Miss Alice McLaughlin, who states that she holds a Second Class License and attended the Provincial Normal School during the current year. She is now teaching at Mundleville. Mr. Ryan makes no recommendation and I would recommend that he be asked to do so unless patronage is to be considered.

[Signature]

December 8th, 1913.

Sir:

Referring to your letters of the 8th and 15th ultimo, enclosing applications from Miss Babain and Miss McLaughlin for the position as teacher of the Big Cove School.

In reply, I beg to say that in view of Miss McLaughlin's professional qualifications, the Department considers it advisable to engage her. Her duties to commence the 8th January and her salary to be the same as paid Miss Sutton, viz., $400.00 per annum.

The Department trusts that you will give Miss McLaughlin full instructions and every assistance that you can in order that her work in this school may be a success.

Please advise Miss Babain of the action taken.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

R. A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.
December 9th, 1913.

Rev. Sir:

Referring to your letter of the last instant, advising the Department that you had received the resignation of the teacher of Big Cove School.

I beg to say that the Department has offered the position to Miss Alice McLaughlin of Mundleville, who is the holder of a Second Class License and a graduate of the Provincial Normal School.

The appointment is being made through the office of Mr. Superintendent Irving.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Jan. 14, 1914.

Mr. R. A. Irving,
Buctouche, N.B.

Dear Sir:

I am sending you this Requisition. I could not fill out the columns "Date of last receipt" as I did not know the date or No. authorized.

One of the Indians told me that they wanted one dozen of books for the Church. The name of the book is "Le Paroissien Noté." He also told me the address which was as follows:

La Cie J. A. Langlais & Fils,
Libraire Editeur
171, rue Saint Joseph,
Saint Rock, Que.

Will you please send for them. I hope I may be able to get the articles named in the Requisition soon, for we are very much in need of the same especially.

Alice McLaughlin.
Ottawa, January 29, 1914.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant enclosing a communication from the teacher of the Big Cove Indian School applying for one dozen copies of "Le Paroissien Note" for the church.

In reply I beg to say that the church authorities will have to supply these books themselves.

Report of Supt. J.J. Ryan on Big Cove School.

School was inspected on January 31st, 1914.

Miss Sutton has been teaching now for a few years here and while she has been— the desire to do all in her power to make a success of the work— I am afraid she is not quite able to cope with the conditions that confront her. There is no doubt whatever but that the school is a more difficult one to handle than any of the other schools in my superintendency— and it requires a teacher with very special qualifications to make a success of the work here. These qualities are wanting in Miss Sutton and in consequence the children are not as advanced as they should be. Miss Sutton has not been in very good health this past year and no doubt ill-health added to the fact that she is hardly adapted for work in an Indian School, has somewhat militated against her success at Big Cove.
Ottawa, February 9, 1914.

Rev. Sir,-

In reference to your report on the Big Cove Indian school I have to ask you whether, in case the Department was disposed to dispense with Miss Sutton's services as teacher of this school, as suggested by you, would you be in a position to secure the services of a thoroughly competent person to take her place.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. J. Ryan,
Superintendent of Indian schools,
St. Mary's Ferry, N.B.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of 9th inst., regarding a vacancy in the Big Cove District. I have been informed that Mr. Haughie was placed in charge at that school, the latter having resigned. Should it be necessary, however, at a future date to secure his services, I am thoroughly competent to take charge of that school. I shall make every effort to secure such a person.

Your obedient servant,

John Ryan
Superintendent Indian Schools
Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith a communication from Big Cove Indians regarding the appointment of a new teacher. The Indians are desirous of having Miss McLaughlin removed, and Miss Babineau, who formerly was teacher of this school and who also taught in Burn Church Indian reserve, appointed in her place.

I consider Miss McLaughlin a good teacher and do not know of any reason the band have for her removal, other than they want Miss Babineau in order that she may play the organ for their church services. The Chief advised me that some of the band will not send their children to school unless the change was made.

Kindly instruct me on the matter.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th inst., stating that the Indians desire the removal of Miss McLaughlin, teacher at the Burnt Church School and the appointment of Miss Babin.

While desirous of meeting the Indians' wishes, still, before taking definite steps the Department wishes to know what Miss McLaughlin's qualifications are and also desires you to state more explicitly the Indians' objections to her.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

R.A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.
Sir;

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the above number of the Twentieth Instant, regarding the removal of Miss McLaughlin, as Teacher of the Big Cove Indian school. Since the receipt of your letter I interviewed the Chief, and he advises me that he has no fault to find with Miss McLaughlin, and he considers her a very good teacher. She holds a second-class teacher's license of this Province which she received at the Normal school, Fredericton, N.B. I consider her a very good teacher and would recommend that nothing further be done in the matter and that she still be retained as Teacher of this school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, July 17, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant stating that you have received through Chief John Joseph an application of Miss Martha Isaacs of Restigouche, Que., for position as teacher of the Big Cove School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department was not aware that there is a vacancy at this school, as no intimation has been received that the present teacher, Miss McLaughlin, intends to resign her position.

Your obedient servant,

J.J. McLellan

To the Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from Mr. Joseph, Indian Chief of Big Cove, Kent Co., N.B., stating that he and his family request my daughter Martha to apply at teacher for Big Cove School as she do not agree the degree of their present teacher after the September quarter. Thus, a teacher should be provided who will be more in touch with Indian characteristics than the young lady now in charge, and so he in addition to teaching the regular branches of studies, would also be able to play the organ for their church services and teach the children to sing. I have written to Mr. Sheridan, Ruston, who is in charge of the Maritime Committee at Ottawa, as he has been very busy with the affairs of the Indians who have left the reserve near here. Sheon who taught me in my little school one day in May last, asked me to lend her a few dollars to get a box of provisions. She promised to send me from Ottawa when she got there.

Her draft came to her.
In August, about the twelfth day when our provincial officers came she belongs to Quebec City. She paid my address but sent me out $1.00. She returned to Quebec in Aug. wrote me twice, but I paid no attention. Before her death draft came. Before her death the matter was settled by Mr. Sheridan. Her check comes to the telegraph office as soon as you receive this. She does not pay rent at once. She is ill when she gets her pay. Letter office here to get my check cashed. All ready, I waited but her mother came away about the middle of last week. I did not pay me off. Her school was closed because of influenza & she could not go back. She was very sick. I did not hear from her until now. I am getting him some truth as Mr. Sheridan.
It's known me as a public school teacher in No. 3 for thirty-two years. The bill is $5.79. They further advised me to send a constable to the reserve but they said surely pay me after stating they had paid me being a stipendary down. She felt sorry to put her to further expense so she could get the Indians' grants. Little business is small but my sight prevents me from seeing it. I wrote letters in years of a reg. mail. Now where to send her her other reg. letters? I must draw their money when the Board of Health closes. I think Miss Gideon will have her money for the future during which...
Indian Reserve school is closed & I ask you to please pay me my bill of $5.19 out of the Indian school. If you will not send it to me, I will go to pay Mr. Sherrida where he will testify as to the veracity. Kindly do the best you can for me. After Paul left from our school, I wrote to you & please see me paid him also asking Gordon to let me know about William. This letter is your calling of family. Mr. Scott,

Rev. Father Ryan, Superintendent of Indian Schools, was requested to investigate the trouble at the Big Cove School, which was brought to the attention of the Department by Mr. Superintendent Sheridan last month.

Miss Roach has been laid up with the influenza and when well is unable to maintain discipline and, judging by her letters, lacks qualifications. The situation of this Reserve so far removed from white people makes it hard to get a good teacher to teach there.

The only thing that will induce a good teacher to sacrifice herself in such a place and under such conditions would be an extra salary and certain inducements if she would teach Domestic Science. The more work the more pay.

Dear Fr. Ryan,

I went, as you requested, and saw Miss Taylor anent her choice of school. She much prefers Burtt Church as a school for next year. Human nature likes a little variety now and then. So I gave her to understand it would be all right. I called on my way on Miss McLaughlin to learn from her what the contents of her letter were. She told me she asked for $800.00 per annum, but had no fancy for the job. I also spoke to others; but a negative was the reply. An Indian school does not appeal to our white race or the Irish school of thought. A French girl would, I think, be more practical and not mind.

As a last resort, I called on Miss Frances Schultz of Bridgetown. She taught the Indian school at Kel Ground some years ago; but the Indians got it into their heads that "Selfdetermination" should be the ideal, applied for an Indian, —one who could address them and teach them in their own language. So, was told that her resignation might be accepted. She left. Now, last night I coaxed her to resume teaching and accept the principalship etc., etc., of Kel Ground Academy. She was to write you this morning, and make the necessary application. I would that advise that the application be favorably considered.

The Indians are going to have a picnic on Labor Day. They want to give me something out of the proceeds, should anything be left. I get nothing from them by way of support; and they are not killed with generosity. Poor people!

Dear Sirs:

I inspected Big Cove Ind. day school on last Monday the 2nd, where were present 18 children and the "REGISTER" showed fair attendance for this time of the year when so many are absent, and so much work requiring help.

Mrs Peter Clair and her husband are leaving nothing undone to get the Big Cove Ind. day school. It is the salary that is so inviting. As for her teaching, I have already reported on same. It is nothing less than a huge "FARCE" -- Children reading in the 4th & 5th READING who should be in the 2nd, &c., and all other subjects run in the same way.

Mrs Savage, the present teacher, has a little boy, about 3 years of age, who is being sent to Montreal to attend the deaf & dumb school. He was there last year. She does not allow this boy to attend the Ind. day school.

Mrs Savage informed me that Mrs Peter Clair was a frequent visitor to her house and informed her that she (Mrs Peter Clair) did not want the Big Cove School yet at the same time she was writing to me for the school.

To make matters worse, Mrs Peter Clair feels so confident in her teaching ability, that she states in one of her enclosed letters, that she intended having her PUPILS ready for "HIGH SCHOOL". What "HIGH School" she means I really do not know.

We were most fortunate in getting Mrs Savage for the present. She is well qualified to teach and is taking a deep interest in the children. Sir:

I beg to inform you that Miss Miriam Dunphy, teacher, and Miss Elizabeth McDade, assistant teacher, of the Big Cove Indian Day School, have forwarded their resignations to take effect at the end of the present month, and the same have been accepted.

The salary allowed Mr. Whalen as teacher will be at the rate of $650 per annum supplemented by the bonus provided by law which is at the rate of $150 per annum. Besides he will be allowed $50 per annum as caretaker and $50 for his services as truant officer. Mrs. Whalen, who is to perform the duties of assistant teacher and matron and instruct the girls in sewing and household work, will be paid at the rate of $450 per annum, supplemented by the bonus of $150 per annum. Main River, N.B.
April 7th

Dear Father,

Enclosed you will find my report for the month of March.

As you will notice they made very little progress, due to so many of the children having the mumps while others stayed home on account of not wishing to take the disease to smaller ones at home as well as being afraid themselves. Some of the children were away on account of no clothing.

The Indians are very poor this year and there is little or no work around here. They are beginning to move away already and a lot more plan on going away as soon as fishing starts along the shores.

Oliver Simon had been poorly this winter and now he is having boils. He dislikes history so I told him we would take very little of it as you see by the report.

Your obedient servant,

Edward Walker.
Main River, N.B.

SPECIFICATION of Proposed Schoolhouse to be Built at Big Cove, New Brunswick.

Dimensions. To be one story, 28 by 20 feet, 10 feet high to top of wall plates from the floor, and 14' 3" from floor to the highest point of ceiling. See drawing.

Foundation. Dig a trench the full size of the building and porch two feet deep and two feet wide and carefully hand lay a dry wall to the height of the ground, then upon this dry wall build with fair sized building stones a mason wall, with good well tempered mortar, 16 inches in thickness and one foot deep well bonded, with perfectly even surface ready to receive the outside sills of the building and porch, and to receive the centre sill built 3 piers in the same manner as the walls 18 inches square, all the walls and piers to have the earth well rammed on each side of them when the mason parts are dry, and to be embanked up to the sills on both sides.

Sills & Joists. Place upon a bed of mortar on the foundation, walls, and piers, sills 6 by 6 inches all around the main building and porch, and also the centre longitudinal sill, the whole to be properly halved at the corners and dovetailed into each other where necessary, and all thoroughly spiked or pinned together with elm pins. Upon the sills place the
the joists 8 by 2 feet apart centres, well nailed to the sills and having one tier of herring bone bridging of 2" by 2" stuff well nailed.

Scantling.

The studding to be of scantling of 2" by 4" stuff doubled at the corners, and window and door jambs, well braced with two rows of braces and set 16" centres ready for lathing or sheeting, lower tier of braces to be 3 1-2 feet from floor.

Roofing.

The roof or wall plates are to be 2" by 4" doubled, of long lengths with at least 2 feet scarf well spiked together and to the studding. The rafters to be 2" by 6" properly notched to fit the wall plates and well spiked thereto, having diagonal collars as shown on drawings to act as ceiling joists, the diagonal collars where they cross each other are to be let into each other with a half inch box taken out of each timber, and the whole of the joints being well spiked together. Rafters to be placed 2 feet centres and to overrun the roof as shown on drawings. Upon the rafters nail good inch boards closely laid together having a covering of tarred felt paper, upon which nail first class shingles set 5 inches to the weather, with weather boards 5 inches wide surmounted with 3 inch circular roll. Finish the roof with a pinnacle, as shown on drawings, to school and porch, as also barge boards and cornice. The rafters and collar beams to porch to be 2" by 4" stuff collar beams 9 inches above fan light.

Sheeting.

The outside of walls to be covered with rough boards and then with best clap boards, having under them a good layer of tarred felt paper, carefully lapped at the joints.

Sheet
Sheet the whole inside of the building and porch with tarred paper well lapped upon which put on diagonally 7/8 inch V jointed dry sheeting free from black or loose knots, shakes, or gum seams.

In the event of plaster being used instead of V jointed sheeting, then the inside of the walls of the school shall be lathed and receive 2 coats of plaster, one coat of plaster being first put on, then the wainscoating to the height of 3 1-2 feet from the flooring surmounted with a 2" inch cap and the facings to the windows and door jambs to be put on, then the second coat to be put on, the wainscoating to be of narrow widths of V jointed stuff put upright; finished at the floor with one inch by one inch strip as here shewn; the ceiling joists or collar beams of the rafters to be covered with tarred paper, then to be battened at 16 centres and lath and plastered two coats. The plaster to be made with clean water, good sharp sand and stone lime well rendered and mixed with a due proportion of cow's hair, the whole to be run a week before using. Angle head and plaster the chimney breasts.

Floor the school and porch with 1 1-2 tongued and grooved good flooring not more than 6 inches in width closely laid and blind nailed. The flooring not to have any black or loose knots or gum seams.

A platform to be made on the floor of the school where shewn on drawings to have joists 2" by 6", and covered with 1 1-2 flooring, with nosing, and neatly made.

Provide and hang with 3 - 4" butts two four-paneled doors 2 inches thick, 7 feet high, and 3 feet
feet 9 inches wide, having rebated frames 2 1-2 inches thick. Fix and provide best 6" American locks to each door, with two keys to each, and suitable furniture. The doors to open outwards.

Provide and fix seven English sashes 1 3-4 inches thick of best stuff to receive 15" by 28" glass, prime, bed, point, and back putty all the glass, supplying all stops and fastenings.

Steps.

Provide and fix front door steps as shown on drawings, firmly and well made, and resting on sunk cedars or tamarac posts, having 2 inch covering, with nosing.

Chimney.

Build with best burnt brick a chimney and stack as shown on drawings, starting support 7 1-2 feet from the floor, firmly frame into two 4" by 4" studs placed there for the purpose, and bolt thereto diagonal braces, and build the reupon a flat frame made as shewn on drawings, covered with 3" inch plank, the chimney where passing through the ceiling frame for further support between cellar beams. Well parge the flue throughout, which is to be 8" by 8" full, place pipe hole as shown on drawings, with ring and stopper. The stack to be finished as shewn. Fix chimney flashings.

Painting.

Knot, prime, stop, and paint with two-coated work, priming all the inside wood work except the floors with Sherwin and Williams paint. The outside of building, except roof, to be painted with two coats of paint made with raw linseed oil and good white lead properly mixed with such other colours as the officer in charge of the work shall choose, also knot and stop where necessary. Fix and paint with three good coats the black board where shewn on drawings.

Facings.
The facings outside, to the door and windows, to be plain, and as shewn on drawings. The sills of the windows and doors to be of tamarac, properly throated and weathered. The inside architraves to be 4" by 1", and for doors 6" by 1", O.G. moulding to surmount as finish of 2 1-2" by 3 1-2" for doors.

Barge boards as shewn on front elevation to school and porch to be fixed with pinnacle, a plain barge board will be put to the rear gable for finish, a hatchway (2' X 2') two feet square to be placed in ceiling for access to the attic, and two rough boards will be nailed on cellar beams to pass from one end of attic to the other. The trap for the hatchway to be attached to frame with 2 - 3 inch butts and admit of being easily opened and shut to act as ventilator. Also 4 ventilators as shewn on Plan, with registers of metal in the base-board to conduct the air to the attic.

Clothes Hooks. Supply and fix 50 strong double clothes hooks on buttons 1 1-4" X 5" well spiked to the studs of the porch and school, 15 to be put in the porch and 35 to be put in the schoolroom, all 5 feet from the floor.

Seats. Provide 21 double seats with desks, 5 of 22 inch high, 5 of 23 inch high, 5 of 24 inch high, and 6 of 26 inch high.

Supply a good table with drawer and lock and key. Table 2' 8" in height and 2 1-2 X 3 1-2 top surface, and three good plain chairs, also a cup-board 6 feet high by 2 feet square, with shelves, door, lock, and key.

General. The whole of the work is to be executed in a workmanlike manner; The materials used for the
the construction to be good in all respects, and to be put together in a thorough manner.

Bell.

Supply and fix a bell and bell cot ready to receive bell as shown on drawings, to be firmly bolted to diagonal collars and rafters having hatchway and secure covering; weight of bell not to exceed 20 pounds.

No extras are allowed unless permitted in writing by the officer in charge of the work and assented to by the Department. The contractor is to supply all plant and materials for construction and carrying on the building to its termination.

Any dispute in connection with the work is to be decided by the Department's officer, from whose decision there will be no appeal. The drawings and specifications are the property of the Department, and are to be returned, otherwise a charge will be made for them.

Winter Sash.

Or double windows, are also to be supplied to all the windows, seven in number.

Sir,

I have to inform you that a petition purporting to be signed by John Peters and other members of the Big Cove Band, has been received protesting against any of the funds of the Band being used for the erection of a school-house or payment of a teacher's salary.

The Department would like you to inform the Indians of this Band that in view of the number of children of school age on the Reserve it is decided to establish a school there and that tenders have been called for the erection of a building, which will be put up this spring. The Department paying two-thirds of the cost and the balance, about $100, to be taken from the funds on the credit of the Band, as it knows of no way in which this money should be spent to better advantage. The Band having only about $300 to their credit, there would be no interest money of any account to distribute, and the Indians should be only too glad to have an opportunity to contribute to such a laudable object. The Department has the power to authorize the expenditure of Indian funds for such purposes, and the Indians should be so informed.

I may add that the Band is not being asked to contribute anything towards the salary of a teacher, which will be paid by the Department when the school is opened.

Your obedient servant,

W.D. Carter

Of all work that I have ever seen done the job on this school is the limit. It is tragic in the extreme. Who is responsible for the farce? I know not.

It is impossible for the teacher to take any interest in the school unless her surroundings are made better. Her old desk is but an old table and the school room but a mere woodshed compared with the rest of the Indian schools throughout the province.

The Department's attention should be given in earnest to this reservation and school. When the teacher arrived she had no place to board and finally got two rooms in the chief's house. I thought the teacher's house theme should have been prepared for her.

Under the careful care of Miss Isaacs I believe this school will improve. She is the best teacher I could get, at present among the Indian schools of the province. In going there I promised her that she would have a good home and school all newly arranged, for I expected the Department to carry out my reports as best they could. When Miss Isaacs arrived she found the teacher's apartments there so filthy that she was forced to get rooms in the Chief's house. The painting in the schoolhouse is poorly done. The kalsomine over the plaster was so thin that it would have been better if the school had never been touched. The plaster is still broken. The teacher has an old table for a desk.

Whether the interior of the school is done in "Bee's Beer", or the man or men were under its influence, I cannot say, yet, it is fine production of some unbalanced brain.

FUEL.

There was neither coal or wood at this school when I was there.

F. C. Ryan.

This old school building is little better than a woodshed and as soon as the new school is built it would be a good plan for the Dept. to have same hauled near the new school for a woodshed and storehouse. This old school would be most useful in this respect and would save the Dept. from building a new woodshed. The old building is a well framed building, straight in every way, and is in good condition for a first class woodshed. Therefore, if hauled across the road it would form a most important adjunct to the new set of buildings.

Memorandum:

With reference to the advisability of proceeding, without delay, with the erection of a combined school and teacher's residence at Big Cove, N. B., I have to report that the present school building is very old and entirely unsuitable for the purpose. The reserve is the most populous in the province and 40 children are in the immediate neighborhood. Father Ryan has urged for the past 4 years that a new school be built on this reserve.

We have had extreme difficulty in the matter of securing a proper teacher at this point, largely because of the lack of residential facilities. The solution is to provide living quarters above the classroom, for a teacher.

Sir:

Mr. Sutherland, of this Department, who visited the Big Cove School on the 11th instant, states that it will be necessary to have a well dug for the use of the new school and teacher's residence. You may, therefore, arrange with a competent person to drill a well of the required depth, and you should purchase a pump of the type required, as well as the necessary piping and casing. It is considered that the cost of drilling should not exceed $50 per foot, and that a depth of approximately 50' should be sufficient to obtain an ample supply of water. This well should be drilled and completed before the winter sets in.

It will also be necessary to obtain a stove for the classroom of the new school. It is considered that a box stove not exceeding approximately $35 would be satisfactory for the purpose. You should also purchase the quantity of stove pipe required. If possible, competitive prices should be obtained, and the purchase of a stove of the type considered satisfactory should be made in ample time to have it set up before the school opens.

As this is a new building, it should be furnished with a fire extinguisher. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase and delivery of a 24 gallon fire extinguisher, properly charged and ready for use. This should be placed in some convenient position in either the schoolroom or the teacher's living quarters.

With reference to the old school building, it is considered that, if this building were removed from its present site and placed near the new school building, directly in front of the coal shed, it would be of great use as a playroom, or for storage purposes for the use of the pupils and teacher. You may, therefore, arrange early this coming winter to have this old school building moved. Mr. Sutherland discussed this matter with you, and in moving the building you should carry out his instructions. When the building is moved, it should be placed on stone piers, the stone now under the building should be used for that purpose. It is considered that it will be possible to have the building moved at an expenditure not exceeding approximately $50.

The toilets at the old school building may remain where they are, and, if required, they can be used in connection with the hall.

The desks in the old school building should be removed, and, as they are of no further use, they may be broken up, or disposed of.

Sir:

Last summer in your letter dated July 4th, reference was made to painting the school buildings of the Big Cove Indian Reserve. But it was not thought necessary to have the work done until this year.

I have recently visited the above mentioned school, and find that the buildings should be painted this summer.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the Big Cove Indian Day School, states that very fine mesh window screens should be provided, in order to keep out mosquitoes. He states that seven screens are required for the school and four for the teachers' residence. If you consider that these screens are necessary, you may arrange for the purchase and installation of same. It is not intended that any unnecessary expense be incurred for the purpose.

The Inspector also states that the drain from the teachers' residence portion of the school should be opened and repaired, as water lies in the cellar all spring and summer. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding this drain, stating what you would recommend be done, and the approximate cost of same.

The Inspector further states that the teachers require a heater in their residence, as it is very cold in winter. I shall also be pleased to have a report regarding this matter, giving the approximate cost of supplying a heater of a type that would be satisfactory.

I shall also be pleased to have a report from you regarding the Inspector's recommendation that a small shed be built against the old school building, in which the teacher can store his car. It may be that if the rough lumber, nails, etc., were supplied for the purpose, the teacher could put up this shed himself. Please furnish your suggestions regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto,
N.B.

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 26th, File No. 55-1-5 referring to recommendations of Rev. Father Ryan concerning the Big Cove school, I beg to say that window screens are necessary, but 4 for the school and 3 for the teachers residence will be sufficient.

In regard to the drain from the teachers residence I have to say that the only remedy for the water lying in the cellar, would be to dig a drain from the cess pool to the river. This will be a distance of about 40 rods. And in this drain will have to placed 4" tiling. The condition of the soil where these buildings are situated is of such a nature that the cess pool fills and the water backs into the cellar. A piece of work like this will cost about $250.00. I would say that if this work was to be authorized by the Department it could be done principally by the Indians with a competent foreman, and would relieve the unemployment among them for a while.

In case of a heater being supplied for the teachers residence I would recommend a small cabinet heater that would not cost more than $25.00. I think it necessary that a heater of some sort be supplied.

If the lumber could be supplied for a shed to be used by the teacher for storing his car, the work will be done without any cost to the Department. The lumber necessary should not cost more than $75.00 with about five dollars extra for nails and hinges for the door. I think this shed is really necessary.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

In your letter of July 11th, authority was given me to purchase lumber for the amount of $25.00 for the erection of a shed for storing the teacher's car. When the shed is erected it will just take that amount of lumber to provide the frame and rough boarding for the outside. The roof needs covering; and also a floor is required. I will have to ask the Department to authorize the expenditure of about $30.00 additional, for to complete this shed.

It might seem extravagant to the Department, to build this shed, but it is necessary for the teacher to have a car in order that he can get away from Big Cove on week ends. Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, relative to the authority which was given you to purchase lumber to an amount not exceeding $25 to erect a shed in which to store the teacher's car at the Big Cove Indian Day School, and requesting that an extra amount of $30 be granted in order to complete this work.

In this connection I beg to say that Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of this school, states that it would be advisable to have, in connection with this garage, a storeroom in which to store the double windows, screens, etc. He states that a storeroom is greatly needed, as everything is always very untidy about the place due to want of a proper storeroom. Would you recommend that space be provided for storage facilities over the shed or garage used for the storing of the teacher's car? If so, the Department would be prepared to authorize the expenditure necessary to have storage facilities provided. I shall be pleased to have, as soon as possible, your views as to the suggestion of the Inspector. If you recommend that these storage facilities be provided, you might furnish an estimate of the cost of the material required, stating whether the teacher could do the work without cost or whether it would be necessary to pay for part of the labour.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N.B.

Sir:

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, requesting that a grant be provided for the purpose of purchasing supplies for a midday meal for the pupils of the Big Cove Indian Day School during the present winter months.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of a midday meal being furnished the pupils from January 1st to approximately the middle of April, next, and you may arrange from time to time for the purchase of the supplies necessary. These supplies should be of the same type as were furnished last winter. The total cost of these supplies for the period the meal is to be served is not to exceed in the aggregate the sum of $55. You should see that all costs are kept as low as possible and that no waste is incurred. You should, as far as possible, obtain competitive prices, and these supplies should only be furnished from time to time as required in order that there will be no wastage. You should also arrange with the teachers for the serving of this midday meal beginning with the date mentioned above. It is expected that, as a result of serving this meal, there will be a regular attendance of Indian children.

Please forward accounts from time to time, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of these supplies.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the Big Cove Indian Day School, recommends that certain cleaning and painting, as well as some repairs, be carried out to the interior of the school building and to the old building used as a domestic science room.

Sir:

This school has been heated by stoves since it was built, and, as far as the Department is aware, this was satisfactory. If you consider that the installing of a furnace is urgent, you should state the type you would recommend and the approximate cost of supplying and installing it. The Department has incurred considerable expense at this school during the past few years and is not prepared to provide the cost in connection with the installation of a furnace, unless same is considered necessary to properly heat the school and residence.

I shall be pleased to have your early report concerning the necessity of a furnace, which should be independent of the teacher's opinion.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 12th, instant referring to heating the Big Cove Indian Day School, I beg to say the stove has been moved about in two or three different directions to try if it would give satisfaction, but without favourable results.

When the stove is placed far enough from the chimney to heat the rear of the school, it will not draw properly, and smokes the school room; and then when it is moved near enough to the chimney to make it draw, it is too far from the rear of the room to heat it. So that is the situation. On very cold days the children have to be huddled together up near the stove, and cannot occupy the rear seats at all.

I do not know of any other way to heat this school than by using a pipeless furnace: This I am sure would solve the problem.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the Big Cove Indian Day School, recommends that a sand table be supplied. You may arrange to have a table suitable for the purpose built locally, keeping all expense as low as possible. This table should be installed in the school where required by the teacher.

The Inspector also recommends that the interior woodwork of the school be well washed, and that the floors should be scrubbed, and, when dry, given a coat of oil. You may arrange to have this work carried out. You should also arrange to have the toilets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition.

The Inspector further recommends that the domestic science room in the old school building be sheeted with beaver board, as he states the plaster is falling off. I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of the material and labour in having this work carried out. Please furnish this information at an early date.

The Inspector also recommends that in the Fall the school grounds be plowed, as the teachers are most anxious to have the grounds placed in good condition. You should arrange to have any bushes near the school cut down and removed, in order to prevent fire hazard. You should bear this matter in mind and have these grounds plowed early this coming Fall, and any brush or bushes removed.

It is also recommended that a furnace be installed. In this connection I would refer you to your letter dated October 5th, last, giving an estimate of the cost. Our funds this year are extremely limited and, unless there is urgent need for alteration in the heating arrangements, we would not be prepared to consider the installation of a furnace. I shall be pleased to have a further report from you regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacNairty,

Dear Sir,

Now that the schools have commenced their fall term I find that there are a few children to be vaccinated and inoculated and we are getting these completed. In visiting the schools I am stressing routine tooth brush drill, administration of cod liver oil and personal cleanliness. Regarding the latter, I am asking the teachers to have a basin, soap (lifesaver preferred), nail brush and towels always in readiness, in case of need. I hope that we will be able to resume milk lunches in the schools next winter. I would recommend that the children of all reserves (excepting Tobique and Saint Mary's) be supplied with good bread and butter along with their milk. I am asking the teachers to appoint one of the older children to be responsible for the cleanliness of the medical supply cupboards.

I would like to visit all of our New Brunswick schools before making the proposed trip to Nova Scotia. This would probably take another three or four weeks. I would then be ready to go to Nova Scotia about the first or second week of October.

Yours very truly,

Sgd: Mary L. Murdoch,
Public Health Nurse for N. B.

EXTRACT from Report of Rev. F.C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for N. B., regarding his visit to the BIG COVE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on May 29, 1934.

Original on File 55-1-6.

The old school building must be equipped at once for at least 3 grades - as a Primary Dept., that it might accommodate some 30 pupils. For a year now, the poor little children have been sitting on high benches about 4 tables used for Domestic purposes, in their Domestic Science hall. We are now forced to turn our Dom. Science hall into a primary dept.

Desks for 30 children, a map for the Maritime Provinces, 3 or 4 blackboards, a teacher's desk, cupboard, will be required. As for cards and the rest, all can be brought over from the new school. Mr. Fraser has more than he can do with the 6 higher grades. Next year, he will have about 30 in his Adv. Dept. and his wife will have about the same number in the old schoolhouse for a Primary Dept.

Re desks for the old school - Mr. Fraser could give some from his Dept. to the old school. These are single desks, iron legs & sides. I would advise purchasing same so that, when either Department would require a few more, or less, same could be brought back and forth from each building. 20 new seats would be enough - I think eight could be obtained from the new school.

Double windows should be purchased for the old school, it is an excellent building, quite warm, in fact a better building in this respect than the new one.

The inside of the new school must be calcimined and cleaned. It is very dirty. The inside of teacher's house should be done.

The outhouses must be cleaned and whitewashed and repaired.
Ottawa, June 28, 1934.

Sir:

In his report regarding his visit to the Big Cove Indian Day School on the 29th ultimo, Inspector Ryan writes as follows:

"The old school building must be equipped at once for at least 3 grades - as a Primary Dept., that it might accommodate some 30 pupils. For a year now, the poor little children have been sitting on high benches about 4 tables and for domestic purposes, in this their domestic science hall. We are now forced to turn our domestic science hall into a primary department.

Desks for 30 children, a map for the Maritime Provinces, 3 or 4 blackboards, a teacher's desk, a board, will be required. As for cards and the rest all can be brought over from the old school. Mr. Fraser has more than he can do with the 6 higher grades. Next year, he will have about 30 in his Adv. Dept. and his wife will have about the same number in the old schoolhouse for a Primary Dept.

Re desks for the old school - Mr. Fraser could give some from his Dept. to the old school. These are simple desks, iron legs and sides. I would advise purchasing same so that, when either Department should require a few more, or less, same could be brought back and forth from each building. 20 new seats would be enough - I think eight could be obtained from the new school.

Double windows should be purchased for the old school, it is an excellent building, quite warm, in fact a better building in this respect than the new one.

The inside of the new school must be kalsomined and cleaned. It is very dirty. The inside of teacher's house should be done.

The outhouses must be cleaned and whitewashed and repaired."

Please let the Department have a full report regarding the situation at Big Cove. You should keep in mind that our Appropriation is limited and that no heavy expenditure can be authorized. In replying, you state which improvements recommended by Inspector Ryan you consider necessary, and give an estimate of their cost. In the case of the desks, you should state the minimum number that would meet the requirements at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N.B.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of June 28th, File 55-1-5 referring to the situation of the schools at the Big Cove Reserve. In reply I beg to say in regard to the necessity of providing more seats and desks, the case is about as the Inspector says it is. There are more pupils than can be accommodated in the new school building, and it does require that more seats should be supplied, and 20 would be the number. The type of seats in the new school building are named the "Silent Sanitary School Desks" these were purchased from Rhodes Curry Ltd., Amherst N.S. I might state that the seats required are single, and cost $7.00 each.

In regard to double windows for the old school, there is no need to purchase new ones as the old windows are in good condition except for the need of a few panes of glass.

The inside of the new school should be cleaned and kalsomined, and also the inside of the teachers residence should be treated the same. The expense for all the work and material to do all cleaning and necessary repairs should not cost more than $25.00. This will cover whitewashing and repairs for toilets.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 21, 1934.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant, I beg to say that you may purchase the new panes of glass that are required at the Big Cove Indian Day School. The inside of the school and the inside of the teacher's residence may be cleaned and kalsomined and the toilets whitewashed and repaired. It is noted that the cost of the materials and labour will not exceed $25.00.

Regarding the 20 new desks, it is noted that you can secure these at a cost of $7.00 each, from Rhodes, Curry, Limited, Amherst, N. S. Please arrange for the purchase and installation of these desks. When placing the order, you should inform the firm regarding the ages of the children for whom the desks are required, in order that they can supply the proper sizes. When forwarding the usual account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the desks, you should quote as your authority E. R. No. 2407.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKensie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, January 26, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, informing the Department that, as a result of a reduction in the supply of milk to the Indians, the Chief has ordered all the children on the reserve to remain at home and not attend school and, also, that he demands the removal of the teacher.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is not prepared to make any increase in the supply of milk. However, it has been decided that it would be of advantage to the children who attend school to provide them with a lunch at midday. You may therefore incur an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $60 in the purchase of food and supplies for the lunch for the pupils during the months of February and March, next. No doubt, Mr. Fraser, with the assistance of the older girls, could prepare and serve the lunch. We understand that there is a stove on which to prepare the hot lunch. Should any utensils be required, you may arrange for their purchase and delivery. I would request that you consult Mr. and Mrs. Fraser at the earliest possible moment regarding the food supplies required and the serving of the meal. It is thought that, if the children received a warm lunch at midday, there would be no objection to their attending school regularly. It is suggested that the lunch consist of soup with meat and vegetables and tea or cocoa. Condensed milk could be used for the latter. Please arrange at once for the purchase of the supplies, from firms on the approved list, and have the goods delivered to the school.

It is hoped that, as a result of the providing of a lunch at midday, the objection of the Indians to

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N.B.
allow their children to attend school will be overcome. In any event, this is all the Department is prepared to grant in the way of extra supplies for relief.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, for all purchases which you make. These accounts should be attached by you to proper voucher forms, certified in the usual manner and forwarded for payment.

Regarding the attitude taken by the Chief, I would request that you forward a further report concerning his activities in discouraging the attendance of the children. If satisfactory evidence is produced in connection with his actions in contravention of Section 10 of the Indian Act, consideration will be given to deposing him from his position as chief. You might state if you would recommend that this action be taken.

Please advise the Department, after the serving of the lunch has commenced, the result in the increased and regular attendance of the children. The Department does not desire to take any drastic action by having the Mounted Police visit the reserve.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I would request that you arrange to have the interior of both buildings thoroughly cleaned during the summer holidays, keeping costs as low as possible. Please forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo regarding painting the schools in your Agency I may say that there is an amount of $300.00 available for repairs and improvements. This sum may be used for painting one or two schools.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of the 26th ultimo, with reference to additional repairs that you consider are needed at the Big Cove School.

We would appreciate it if you would review the matter again and advise us if the absolutely necessary work could be done this year for a much lower cost than that mentioned in your letter.

Are we to understand that each of the firms mentioned in your letter of the 26th quoted the same price for the labour?

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. E.J. Blakey,

Rogersville, N.B.

We have your requisition of November 29th requesting 24 new desks for the Big Cove School and one teacher's desk and chair.

Purchase of the above will involve a rather heavy expenditure and our funds at the present time are limited. Would a less number of desks provide sufficient seating capacity?

We do not understand why the attendance has increased to such an extent that apparently 24 new desks are required.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

In reply to your 275-4 (E.l) of the 3rd inst in connection with the above mentioned requisition, I wish to say that three families have recently arrived at the Big Cove Reserve after being in the United States for several years, this added 7 pupils to the list. Previous to this there had been a shortage of desks. In the Junior Day School, approximately twelve children are using long benches placed around a large table, while in the Senior Day School one bench and a long table are being used.

Twenty-four desks were requisitioned so that each child might have desk. However, during the winter months there will be a smaller average attendance so that the present accommodation will not be so strained. If half the number of desks specified on our requisition of November 29, 1948 could be supplied, it would improve the seating situation in these days two Day Schools.

The breakdown in desks would be as follows: 6 Large and 6 Small.

Yours very truly,

[E.J. Blakey]

Sir,

In further reference to your letter number 120886/5 in re. estimate of the costs of building a two roomed cottage for the Teacher at Big Cove, Kent County, New Brunswick, and in reply I may say, that I have prepared an estimate and I find that if a building is placed as a lien to the rear of the present school house, that the same can be built, giving two rooms, 10 ft. by 15 ft., for approximately $150.00. I think that it would be much more convenient to have it adjoining the school house, as it would be warmer in the winter time, and the Teacher could have access to the school from her cottage, without going outside. If this building is built separate and apart from the school house, it will cost about $300.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Ottawa, December 27th, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant stating that the two-roomed cottage can be erected as an addition to the Big Cove school-house to provide accommodation for the teacher at an approximate cost of $150.00.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has no funds at present to put up this addition, but hopes to be able to undertake the work when the estimates for next year are available. In the meantime I should be glad if you would forward further details as to the material, construction, etc., of the lean-to which you could have erected for this sum. The Department is of the opinion that a lean-to with an entrance from the school is preferable to a separate building.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to inform you that being anxious about the arrangements made in the contract I had the teacher at the Big Cove School, Kent Co., &c., &c.

I paid an inspection visit to that reserve on the 27th last while the building in which the teacher is now located is not quite finished—the forms she occupies are finished—but they are not quite sufficiently furnished and therefore it is that I would respectfully suggest to the Dept. the advisability of making these two forms as open for tables as possible—as otherwise it will be exceedingly difficult to get a good table to remain.

I am enclosing list of articles needed by Miss Scott.

I am pleased to state that there is at present a better attendance at the school than has been the case since Miss Scott's teaching at Big Cove and the children and parents both are well pleased with the new teacher.
Miss Sutton while young appears to be a very competent person for her position but feels naturally anxious at her change under present conditions. I gave her all the encouragement I could and assured her the Dept. would do all it could reasonably do to make her present home as comfortable as possible.

In reply to your letter of the 14th, st, concerning the matter of installing a sink in the teachers residence at the Big Cove Indian Reserve. I wish to say that it has taken me some time to get prices on this sink, which is the reason for me not answering your letter sooner.

Ottawa, July 17th, 1925.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his inspection of the Big Cove Indian Day School dated June 23rd, last, recommends that a new cooking stove, a table for cutting out garments and a cupboard, also a few utensils, be installed in the old school building which is used for the teaching of domestic sciences.

Please state the approximate cost of a new stove, also whether you can arrange to have a suitable table and cupboard built, and the cost of same. You might obtain a list from the teacher of the cooking utensils required, and forward an estimate of their cost.

The Inspector also recommends that the woodwork of the new school building be washed, and the floors oiled. He states that the oiling of the floors should be done by a competent man.

He further recommends that the outhouses be cleaned and whitewashed. You may arrange to have this work done with as little expense as possible. He also strongly recommends that a toilet be built for the teacher's use. Please state if you would recommend that this be done, and, if so, the approximate cost of the material and labour in erecting an inexpensive toilet.

You may purchase and have delivered 6 cases of laundry soap, 6 yards towelling and an inexpensive looking glass.

The Inspector also states that the teacher is anxious to instruct the boys in manual training, and requires a set of carpenter tools for the purpose. Please consult the teacher and have him prepare a list of what tools he requires, and furnish an estimate of the cost.

You should arrange this coming fall to have the grounds around the school plowed and harrowed, in order that next spring the teacher can teach gardening to the pupils.

It is expected that you will give all of the above matters your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sept. 5th, 1889,

The Dept. of Ind. Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs:

We have just finished our Convention at North Devon. It was most successful and in due time the Dept. will receive full reports of same.

I wish by this hasty letter to call the Dept.'s attention to a long neglected matter, viz: the opening and the extending of the cellar drain at the teacher's house in Big Cove. The cellar is and has been in a most deplorable condition, flooded with water from the sink, &c., that back up into the cellar.

Again, Mr. Fraser claims that it might be impossible to have school in the Big Cove Ind. school if the coming winter be in keeping with our Country's tradition (the last two winters have been mild) unless a good FORAGE IS PLACED IN SCHOOL. I trust the Dept. will take care for these IMPORTANT ITEMS AT ONCE.

Every encouragement must be given Mr. Mr. Fraser. It would be nothing short of calamity for BIG COVE IND. RESERVE should Mr. Mr. Fraser leave.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Inspector of Ind. Schools, p.m. 1889.

Sir:

A communication has been received from Rev. F. G. Ryan, Inspector of Schools for New Brunswick, in which he draws attention to the condition of the drain from the cellar in the teacher's residence portion of the Big Cove Indian Day School. He states that this cellar is, and has been, in a most deplorable condition - flooded with water from the sink, that backs up into the cellar.

I have to request that you will furnish a report as soon as possible, regarding this drain, and state what you would advise be done in order to overcome the difficulty and to provide proper drainage. You should give an estimate of the cost of any work you recommend be carried out. The Department will expect your early report, in order that, if any work is authorized, it can be completed before the extreme cold weather sets in.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 7th instant referring to a communication from Rev. F.C. Ryan relating to the condition of the cellar of the Big Cove Indian Day School, and in reply I have to say that I have examined the cellar and find that the only way to correct the condition would be to have a drain dug and piping placed to carry the water from the cellar.

The distance from the cellar to where an outlet could be secured is about 200 feet, and the cost will be between $250.00 and $300.00 as the formation through which the drain has to be made is a shell rock and hard to dig. I would say that this drain is necessary.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

The Secretary
Indian Agent
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, relative to the condition of the drain from the cellar of the Big Cove Indian Day School. It is noted you recommend the drain be dug and the necessary piping placed therein to carry the water from the cellar and that the length of this drain to a place where an outlet could be secured would be approximately 200'.

In this connection I have to say that the Department would like to have arrangements made for a satisfactory drainage system for the school and residence portion of the building. You may arrange for the labour required in digging the drain, and you should see that it is dug to a suitable depth below the frost line and at a proper grade to permit of all water running freely from the pipe. You should also arrange for the purchase of the pipe required, and you should see that it is satisfactorily laid in the ditch from the cellar to the outlet, and that all joints are securely fastened, and the drain properly filled in. It is noted you estimate the cost to be approximately $300. If possible, this work should be carried out at a lower cost, as the department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred, having in view the performing of satisfactory work. It is thought that Indian labour could be used under the charge of a competent man who could supervise the work. The teacher might be able to undertake the service, keeping proper time sheets of the labour employed. Please arrange to have this work completed before the extreme cold weather sets in. The drain pipe should be securely connected to the sink in the teacher's residence, and it should also be arranged that any water from the cellar could flow out through the drain pipe. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that a satisfactory job is completed, and at the lowest possible expense.

After the work has been completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the labour employed and for the quantity of piping required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

OTTAWA, 22nd June, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr. Supt. Carter of Richibucto recommends the dismissal of Charles Bernard, teacher of the Burnt Church school, and the appointment of Miss Keating as his successor. Bernard absented himself from the school during the whole of March quarter last, and ever since he has been teaching he has been a constant source of annoyance to the Department through his creditors. He has made a practice of anticipating his salary by giving orders on merchants for more than his actual earnings, and as soon as one claim was satisfied another was sent in for payment. He is an Indian and I think the best thing the Department could do would be to get rid of him on the 30th June. He is carrying on the school this quarter.

Ottawa, June 17th, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

Relative to the communications from the teachers of the Burnt Church Indian Day School which you handed to the department during your recent visit, which they request that increases be granted them, I beg to inform you in view of your report on the work being done at this school, the Department is not disposed to grant any increase for the next school year. We note that the services of the assistant teacher and the work she performed in the teaching of domestic science, etc., has not been very satisfactory.

It is hoped this coming summer to build an addition to the present school building to provide accommodation for the proper teaching of domestic science. Would it not be possible to obtain the services of a married man having the necessary qualifications to perform the classroom work, and his wife could teach domestic science and attend to field matron work on the Reserve? This arrangement has met with success on the Big Cove Reserve, and it is thought that a married teacher and his wife would be better at Burnt Church; it would be more satisfactory than the continuing of the services of the Misses Bransfield. If the services of a competent married man and his wife could be obtained, the Department would be prepared to pay salary at the same rate as is paid at Big Cove. We will leave this matter in your hands and shall be pleased to hear later as to what arrangements you have been able to make for the carrying on of the work of teacher and field matron at Burnt Church.

You may inform the present teachers that it will not be possible to grant them any increase in salary, as it is considered that they receive ample remuneration for the services they render.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
