Ottawa, July 4th, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the communication which you forwarded from Miss Marion Cahoon, teacher of the Red Ground Indian Day School, together with the report of your inspection of this school. It is stated that Miss Cahoon intends to resign her present position, but that she will accept the school at Burnt Church. The Department agrees with your suggestion that Miss Cahoon be transferred as teacher of the Burnt Church School for the school year beginning on or about September 1st, next. If this arrangement can be carried out, the two Cahoon sisters will be together, and this may result in more satisfactory work, both in the classroom and in the teaching of domestic sciences. I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange, if possible, to carry out the above arrangement.

The question of obtaining another school for Miss Stella Bransfield will be left in your hands. If you consider that it would be satisfactory to replace Miss Cahoon at Red Ground, it is stated from the communication which you forwarded from her that she might not want to accept another school. If you succeed in transferring Miss Cahoon to Burnt Church, and cannot arrange any other appointment for Miss Bransfield, you should inform her that her services will not be further required.

The Department will leave the matter of the appointment of teachers for the next school year in your hands, and I shall be pleased to hear definitely at a later date what arrangements have been made by you for the teaching services in the schools in New Brunswick.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF REV. FATHER RYAN,
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS FOR NEW
BRUNSWICK, DATED SEPTEMBER 24, 1929, ON
HIS INSPECTION OF THE BURNT CHURCH INDIAN
DAY SCHOOL.

---

It was agreed last year, when Miss Evelyn Cahoon
was recalled from her duties as field matron, that by an
increase of salary they could also carry on Domestic
Science. They did all that could be expected. The
result is that this branch of our work has about completely
fallen down, and the Reserve looks it. We must do some-
thing to better conditions. It is simply imperative from
every standpoint of view.

I would, therefore, suggest that the Department
send Miss Evelyn Cahoon back at her field work and have
another sister come in and teach the Primary Department.
The Department could take $75 or $100 from both sisters'
salaries and add $300 to this, or $500. This would be
quite enough salary for a Primary teacher. Even $450 would
be a fair salary. Both sisters should be willing to lose
a part of their salary when this extra work is removed from
them. We cannot, with 52 children of school age and the
present state of the Indians on this our largest Reserve,
let things stand as they are. We must meet the difficulty
and surmount same before it becomes unsurmountable. This,
to my mind, is the only solution to the question. It will
be the duty of the Field Matron to be the truant officer
and report on all Indians & children of school age absent from
the Reserve, their whereabouts, etc. This "line-up", with
all her duties of domestic science, caring for the sick,
teaching economy, etc., that she so successfully carried on
before, will be an incalculable one, uniting the present
divergencies with a common unit that can alone spell success to
this Reserve. To here falter would be a huge mistake.
November 13, 1929.

Memorandum:

Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, writes (File 55-2-5) that the services of a field matron are required on the Burnt Church Indian Reserve. In the past, the Department employed two lady workers, both paid from School Vote. One was responsible for the academic work in the classroom - the other for noonday lunch, instruction in sewing, etc., and for field work. Last year, the classroom work, the teaching of domestic science and the preparation of the noonday lunch became so heavy - the average attendance being approximately 40 - it was necessary to let the field work go and to divide the duties at the school proper. At present Miss Marion Cahoon, senior teacher, has five grades and Miss Evelyn Cahoon, her sister, has three lower grades and the domestic science. Their salaries are $300 and $650, respectively. Father Ryan now writes regarding the result of no field matron activity. His letter reads in part as follows: "The reserve looks it. We must do something to better conditions. It is simply imperative from every standpoint. . . . . To falter now would be a huge mistake."

Do you think that you should arrange for the creation of a position and for the voting of $450 or $500 salary for a field matron? Father Ryan nominates a Miss Cahoon, a sister of the two teachers, for the post and suggests the salary mentioned.

February 4th, 1932

Mr. Charles Hudson,
Ind. Agent,
Kichibucto, N.B.

Dear Sir:

As you know Marion has developed tuberculosis, she was ill when she came home in June, and has been bedfast since August. The specialist was here a short time ago and informed us that, while there is some improvement, the lungs have not yet healed, and we do not know how much longer Marion will be bedfast. At any rate she is not to get up until the doctor returns to Edmundston which will be in May or June.

We know this tuberculosis was caused by conditions in the Indian school. My daughter was not predisposed to this disease as we have never had tuberculosis in my husbands or my own family or in our immediate family. The epidemic of whooping cough among the Indian pupils last winter, which Marion contracted from them, weakened her lungs, and apart from this there were tubercular children in the school.

We feel knowing this, and also the years of service Marion gave there, the Dept. would be willing to grant her an allowance, for the necessary care and expense her long illness entails, considering the fact that through her environment, and not by any fault of her own she is ill. The only regret is that she did not leave the school last winter while suffering from whooping cough, but as you know the doctor did not approve of closing the school, we therefore consider school conditions as directly responsible.

Hoping to hear from you as soon as convenient.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a communication from the teachers of the Burnt Church Indian Day School, in which they request permission to defer taking the regular holiday period at Easter until such time as weather conditions permit the use of cars.

Dear Miss Hogan:

I delayed somewhat in accepting your resignation until assured you had decided entering matrimonial life. Your services will be deeply missed by not only the Indians and their children at Burnt Church, but also by the staff of teachers in the N.B. Indian schools, especially at our CONVENTIONS.

Under your four years supervision as principal—the Burnt Church Indian school certainly reached a marked degree of efficiency, both in domestic science, as well as in all educational work—so as to amply including our regular IX Grade as taught in the provincial White Schools, so much so—that now the said school ranks among the foremost Indian schools of N.B.

Your constant devotion to duty in so ably supporting me in higher education for our N.B. Indian schools will ever remain a happy recollection, and while I regret your departure on the one hand,—on the other, I am happy to offer my prayers and best wishes for your future welfare in the new and exalted life you are about to enter.

May God, therefore, bless you and yours with long years of Christian peace and joy.

My Dear Boy Phil:
Your letter received and I must say that I have been besieged for the past two or three years with letters from Bishops, Priests, and the laity for Indian schools. All letters seemingly know about the resignation of teachers, which are not a fact. Teachers write them making up this one same story: "I HEAR THAT SUCH OR SUCH A TEACHER IS RESIGNING" - then asking their influence to get the said Ind. school. All are after the "SALARY," but few are competent teachers for Ind. schools.

In order to get rid of a lot of such teachers I have asked the Dept. to hire only FIRST CLASS SUPERIOR TEACHERS, as they can be obtained for the same salaries, then we have a better chance to choose the most qualified from this few and not be over crowded by useless applications.

Some six or seven years ago, I had no trouble. However, if the Dept. would only refer all applicants to me, I assure you there would be little trouble. I feel Mr. Sutherland well knows this as he has been so often here. I want the very best teachers, whether they be the Rev. sisters or otherwise, I have no favorites whether recommended by priest or Bishop, or politician, I have always found that such teachers that come backed up with influences prove, after a short while, little good and most hard to get rid of.

I have not heard anything about the Miss Hogans resigning. I would be most sorry to lose them, they have done wonderful work.

I am inclosing letters that seem to know, as is always the case, more than the teachers (the Miss Hogans) themselves, about their resignation.

I trust you are well,

Yours respectfully,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant File 55-2-1 with a letter from Mrs. Noel P. Paul, Burnt Church, N.B., referring to school affairs at the reserve. In reply I beg to inform you in the first place, that the letter is not written by Mrs. Noel P. Paul, and then if it were, this woman has no children attending school. I am of the opinion that the letter was written by one of the pupils of the school, and it may be a grandchild of Mrs. Noel P. Paul.

With regard to this letter I have to say that it is just ridiculous, and there is no true statement in it. With regard to relief, it is only deducted when a pupil stays away from school for no good reason, and never when a child is sick. The teachers are just a little too lenient in some cases rather than too severe; and with regard to lost time, they never lose any time from school, without it might be a day now and then by sickness. I might state that the teachers of this school are very capable and are very careful about attending to their duties.

I am returning Mrs. Paul's letter and wish to state that it nothing but a lot of falsehoods.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

your obedient servant

[Signature]

The Secretary

Ottawa.

Last evening I received a telephone call from Rev. Father John Ryan, parish priest of Nelson N.B., enquiring if it would be possible for Miss Frances B. Hartery, teacher of the Burnt Church Indian Day School, to be excused from her duties for the last five days of the present term.

Rev. Father Ryan is having a number of the leaders in his Parish proceed to Montreal to take a summer course on religious education and he would like to have Miss Hartery take the course which opens on June 23rd.

I might say that this course might be very valuable to Miss Hartery in her duties at Burnt Church and if her absence should be approved by the Department, Miss Robichaud would be able to handle the whole school for the last week of the term.

Will you please let me know at once whether this meets with your approval or not.

Indian Agent.

Mr. A. Lee Fraser, Indian Agent, Rexton, N.B.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 20th instant, the Department approves Miss Hartery being excused from duties as teacher for the last five days of the present term. It is noted that during her absence Miss Robichaud will be able to handle the whole school for the last week.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to inform you that Miss Frances B. Hartery, Principal of the Burnt Church Indian Day School, has resigned her position.

For your information I would say that Miss Hartery has received an appointment to Harkins Academy at Newcastle, N.B., which is right at her home.

I had hoped that Miss Lillian Robichaud would have resigned, as her work has not been entirely satisfactory, but owing to the scarcity of teachers, I have been reluctant to ask for her resignation.

I might respectfully point out that the combination of a French and English teacher is very seldom satisfactory, and that where possible, a man and his wife should be in charge of any Indian schools, where two teachers are employed.

I would, therefore, ask your permission to make the best arrangement possible, in regard to this school for next term.

A request has been received from Chief Paul Taylor of the Burnt Church Indian Reserve, to have the annual vacation period of this Indian Day School changed from the usual months of July and August to two winter months, possibly January and February. Memorandum:

INSPECTION OF BURNT CHURCH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Date of inspection - September 8, 1949.

Teachers - Miss Robichaud and Miss Allain whose qualifications and experience are on file.

School - This was formerly a one-room school building to which a second classroom has been added. On the whole the classrooms are quite satisfactory. The building has been newly painted inside and out.

Both these teachers are capable and interested in their work. Miss Allain is the senior teacher and knows her job well. The children should improve under her teaching. Miss Robichaud has the junior grades and her experience has made her a capable primary teacher. She may be willing to transfer to a school in Western Canada.

Recommendations:

1. The provision of a water cooler, cups and coat-hooks.
2. The provision of a sewing machine for the senior room.
3. The provision of blackboards in the junior room.
4. The installation of hydro now on the reserve.

Teacherage -

This is in a separate building and has recently been lined with gyproc and painted. The teachers are quite satisfied with their quarters, particularly as they have now a new stove.

Summary

This is a two-room school in capable hands and the children should progress well. Both buildings will serve for some time.

Nov. 10, 1942

Dear Sir:

I am writing you re my salary. I did receive $75.00 monthly plus $5.00 monthly for being truant officer. Since October, 1941 with the deduction of $6.00 monthly for War Savings Certificate I received $3.09 which was to include living bonus and now since October 1942 I am getting $3.99.

My salary has not been increased as much as the other teachers who have the same number of dependents and who had been receiving the same salary, $80.00 monthly, in the beginning.

If there has been an error since October 1941, I would appreciate an adjustment.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours very truly,
Carmel J. Hogan

Dear Sir:

I beg to acquaint you that the school house is in a very inconveniently located, and that it should be on the side where the Reserve is more thickly settled, and for the following reasons:

First, thirty-five pupils attending school at present time, and out of this number twenty-four residing on the opposite side the river when the school is now situated and only eleven
pupils reside on the side where the school is situated.

Secondly, the road on its own in the place in fact and spring, generally overflows and it is always with difficulty for teachers and pupils to come across when this occurs. Thirdly, in winter time, very many of the pupils will not be able to come to school on account that the school being so far from their homes.

It would not cost much to take the building over to near the church and much comfort would be rendered. The building could be taken down to the shore, which is only little over hundred yards and
then be put on to a
two scows and then

difficulty.
I beg you most

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I enclose a letter received from the teacher of the Burnt Church Indian School, asking that the school building be removed from its present site to the opposite side of the river where the great body of the Indians live. There is no doubt but that the building is in the wrong place and I intended bringing the matter to the attention of the Dept before, but did not do so as I was informed the new building now in course of erection on this reserve was to be used in part for a school house. Since the Indians have resolved to put it to other uses, I think the old school house should be moved to where the Indians, or at least the great body of them, now live. I did think the best and easiest way to move it would be on the ice after it formed, but perhaps Mr. Bernard's idea of moving it on scows would be the better way. The cost I think would not exceed $50 and it might be less.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Supt.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of official letter of 28th Sept. last, and the reason I did not reply sooner was that I wished to visit the reserve personally as I was convinced the Indians would not consent to the proposal or at least the latter part of it. The new building is not yet completed inside, and on looking over the ground I think the better proposal would be if possible to move the school building across the creek from where it is now to a place nearer the Indian village. This could be done on the spot at a cost of not more than $100. When the school building was built the Indians were settled chiefly east of the creek in small log or frame buildings. Now they have settled chiefly on Point and as they have constructed more substantial houses it is probable that the settlement is permanently located. The school house where it now is is about 2 miles from the western end of the reserve and in an inconvenient location for at least nine tenths of the Indian children to attend, as the creek is flooded in spring and fall, and about three hundred yards of the road overflowed.

Ottawa, September 21, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing a communication from Mr. McDonald, contractor for the erection of the Burnt Church School.

In reply I beg to say that the question of whether a wood or coal furnace should be installed in this school is a matter of economy. If wood is plentiful and is the cheaper fuel a wood furnace should be supplied. On the other hand if coal is cheaper and more convenient the furnace should be one to use this fuel. The Department is not in a position to decide and the matter will be left to your discretion.

With regard to the extra price asked for a coal furnace, if you decide to install one of this kind you should make inquiries and allow the contractor the difference, if any.

With reference to the ceiling I may say that in the Woodstock and Oromocto schools the Department has had metal ceilings of an approved pattern put in for the same price as the V jointed pine. As Mr. McDonald asks $45.00 more for the metal ceiling you may instruct him to use the pine.

Kindly advise the Department as to the decision arrived at in regard to the furnace.

Your obedient servant,

My dear Sir—

I have forwarded all unpaid bills to Ottawa by airmail, also a memorandum of money which I spent on the schoolhouse. The schoolhouse is now Church Indian Reserve. Your Secretary will see that immediately behind, and now I take the privilege, dear Sir, to ask you to look into the matter, and let your department consider it to settle the debt. Probably you are aware that before accepting contract, the Department asked me what I would take, and complete schoolhouse, as I was afraid my original tender was too low, and was on the eve of throwing up contract. I sent an answer by telegraph saying five hundred.
dollars, $400/- but before setting a reply I considered the matter & send a telegram accepting at my initial figures, with the hopes after completion thereof for the four hundred I asked.

Now dear Sir, the statement I sent to Ottawa is correct. I sent it personally to Mr. Smith he then had representation. I have asked him to do his best & he will be willing to find out any information & I believe the thanks I should be helped. I am in a first-class job which Mr. Brown, Indian Dept., has not yet been able to fill me also tell me my position in life, & what position I will be placed in if I have to assume the burden of fills. I only wrote into the matter & let me know what the department proposes to do regarding the paying of fills. I mean in first-rate way they mean to depress, if the money in hand.

Trusting you will use your influence

Remain Yours Truly

Ottawa, August 5, 1910.

Mem. re contract for Burnt Church school-house.

On June 15th, last, the tender of Mr. Donald R. McDonald to erect this building for $2375.00 was accepted. Shortly after that Mr. R. A. Irving, Indian Superintendent, of Buctouche, visited Chatham with a view to having the necessary contract and bonds executed, but Mr. McDonald declined to enter into a contract, stating that he made a slight mistake in figuring on the work and asking that he be allowed three to four hundred dollars extra. He was then asked to state the lowest sum for which he would erect the building and the reply received was that he would take four hundred dollars more than the amount of his original tender, which made the amount $2775.00. This placed Mr. McDonald higher than the next lowest tenderer and Mr. Loggie was informed that it was impossible for the Department to give him the contract at a price higher than the next lowest tenderer and that, in any event, it would be necessary to obtain the sanction of His Excellency the Governor General.
in Council. Mr. Loggie then wired on the 28th ultimo that Mr. McDonald would accept the contract at his original price and on the 29th ultimo Mr. Loggie, Mr. Irving and Mr. McDonald were advised that as soon as the contract was signed and the bonds executed the necessary authority to commence the work would be given. These have not yet reached the Department, but immediate action will be taken as soon as they come to hand.

U. P. MacKenzie
Ottawa, January 18, 1911.

Memo.

Mr. Pedley,

Re Burnt Church School Contract.

In regard to Mr. McDonald's contract for this building I would refer to Mr. MacKenzie's memorandum of August 5, herewith, and add that the contract was duly signed and bonds for its performance executed.

The work has been completed and payment to the extent of $1300.00 has been made; the balance being withheld as there are claims against the contractor for materials and cash advanced by a Chatham firm.

An Order in Council was passed accepting the tender of Mr. James Mowat, the lowest tenderer, but on being informed of this he stated that upon further consideration of the plans and specifications he could not do the work for less than $2500.00. Another Order in Council was then passed accepting the next lowest tenderer Mr. McDonald, but before he would execute the contract he looked more fully into the question of the plans and
specifications and he stated that it would cost $400.00 more than the amount of his tender to complete the work. This would bring him up to $275.00 more than the price for which Mr. Mowat said it could be built, namely, $2500.00 so the Department wired Mr. Mowat to have him verify the statement that he would build it for $2500.00 and before a reply in the affirmative was received from him Mr. McDonald advised the Department that he would take the contract at the amount of his original tender, $2,375.00. This was accepted and under this contract he has completed the building. I do not see how we can pay anything more than the contract called for as the claim of Mr. McDonald is not made for extras, but for work done under the original plans and specifications, and Mr. Mowat was willing to erect it for $275.00 less than the amount he now asks for.

2. That I undertook the carrying out of the said contract, and for the purpose aforesaid, applied to John Ferguson and Sons, Limited, of Newcastle in the County of Northumberland, for assistance in a financial way, and also for goods, to enable me to carry on the said contract.

3. That I now am indebted to the said John Ferguson and Sons, Limited, on account of the said contract, for money advanced and goods supplied, in the sum of One hundred and twenty two dollars and ninety cents ($122.90), which money and goods were used by me in defraying the cost of the building of the said School, and the said money and goods were used in the construction of the said property, and for the payment of the sum of Forty ($45.00) five dollars for digging cellar, and Fifty five ($55.00) dollars for wages paid the Indians employed in the erection and carrying out of the said contract.

Ottawa, January 23, 1930.

Sir:

At the end of November, last, you forwarded the recommendation of Travelling Nurse Murdoch for supplies for the serving of a midday lunch to the pupils of the Burnt Church Indian Day School. It is regretted that this was inadvertently overlooked. The Department will be unable to furnish all the supplies, such as the quantity of milk, butter, etc., which the nurse recommended be furnished. Our funds are limited at the present time, and the cost involved would be excessive.

However, the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $50 in the purchase of the food supplies to be used in serving a lunch at midday. It is thought that you could arrange to purchase the quantity of oatmeal cookies, or a suitable biscuit, at wholesale prices. You may arrange also for the purchase of a quantity of cocoa, sugar and dry milk powder and a number of white enamel drinking cups for this purpose.

It is understood that the teachers, with the help of the older girls, will prepare and serve this hot drink, together with a biscuit, to each of the pupils at noon on each teaching day. This lunch is only to be served during the winter months or until the end of April, next. Please give this matter your prompt attention, have the above supplies purchased and delivered as soon as possible. It is presumed that the teachers will make the necessary arrangements to serve the lunch. You should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase authorized.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letters of the 16th, instant referring to slight repairs, cleaning, painting etc., on the four Indian schools in this agency, and in reply will say that these matters will be attended to immediately.

The first thing I would like to take up is the drain from the basement of the Burnt Church school. This drain is about 800 feet long, from the school to where it empties into the river. About 400 feet from the school, the pipe which is 4 inches in diameter, connects with the drain from the basement of the Church, which is also 4 inches in diameter. This size of pipe is not large enough to carry off the volume of water from the both basements.

The only thing that can be done is to dig a trench from where the drain from the school connects with the one from the Church, to the river, and continue the pipe from the school without connecting with the pipe from the Church. This will mean that there will be a separate drain from the school to the outlet at the river without intersecting the drain from the basement of the Church.

This work will cost about $500.00 for labour and material. It is true that for a period last spring, of about six weeks the furnace could not be used on account of the basement being nearly full of water.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Last year the pupils of the Baptist Church Indian Day school were furnished with a mid-day lunch of milk and biscuits from December until May, but during the fall just past it was not thought necessary, as nearly all the Indians of this reserve were getting some relief. But now the children of this reserve nearly all have the whooping cough, and I believe it will be necessary to provide something for them to eat at mid-day.

I would think that cocoa with milk and sugar, and some sort of biscuit would be suitable for this lunch. This would cost about $4.50 per week. I would recommend that this be provided from Feb. 1st until May 1st. I would also recommend that a few provisions be furnished for cooking classes for domestic science branch of this school. This not to exceed $2.00 per week.

Your obedient servant

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the supplying of a midday lunch to the pupils of the Burnt Church Indian Day School during the period from the first instant to the end of April, next.

You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase of these supplies from time to time. It is noted that you estimate the cost to be approximately $4.50 per week. You may also arrange for the purchase of the provisions required for the cooking classes in domestic science, at a cost not exceeding $2 per week. You should arrange for the purchase of the supplies required and have them delivered to the teacher at an early date.

I may say that we have no funds to pay for any of the above expenditure until after April 1st, next, and itemized accounts covering the cost of the above supplies, which should be forwarded in duplicate, attached to proper voucher forms, should not be rendered until after the above date.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant File 55-2-5 referring to the report of Inspector Ryan on the Burnt Church School in which he states that the domestic science building is being painted. In reply I beg to inform you that I certainly am amused at some of the statements made by the Reverend Inspector.

In regard to the painting he saw, it was on a small portion of the wall of the domestic science wing from which the paint had all disappeared and it looked very shabby. When I had a man doing the work authorized by your letter of June 26th File 55-2-5, I asked him to put a little paint on this shabby part (at no cost to the Department). The surface covered was about 10 feet square. It happened that this was not done until quite late and on the day the Inspector visited the school. He may have thought the whole school was being painted, but I cannot understand how he could be mistaken like that.

I trust the Department did not think I would undertake a contract like painting a school without your authority.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 11th instant in which you intimate that certain repairs to the furnace will be necessary at the Burnt Church Indian day school. It is noted that these repairs will involve an expenditure of approximately $22.00 and you are authorized to have this work undertaken at the earliest possible date.

May I point out that it is highly desirable that repairs to Indian day schools should be undertaken and completed during the vacation period. This is the practice invariably followed in the case of public schools and I am anxious that our procedure should be brought into conformity with the practice followed at public schools. The repairing of a furnace or the painting of a building, I know from experience, is a constant source of annoyance to the teacher in charge of any school. I feel confident that you will be glad to co-operate with the Department in at least attempting to have repair work done during the months of July and August.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 24th, 1940, File 56-3-5 referring to painting the interior of the Church School, I beg to inform you that I have had a painter to look at this job, and the lowest cost for material and labour will be $90.00. Part of the work to be painted has been covered with varnish and this will have to be washed off, which makes as much work as the painting itself. I believe the Indians could do this work satisfactorily.

The floors of this building should be cleaned and oiled, and this will cost, for material and labour $7.00, in addition to the cost of painting.

Dear Sir:

When you are trying your best to reduce expenses, it seems that there is just one thing after another turns up upon you. Now it is the furnace at the Burnt Church school that has about given out; It has been repaired one or more times and I do not believe it is worth repairing again, and another thing is that I know a heater that will cost about $45.00 will heat the building better than the furnace that is now used. There is nothing else for me to do but recommend that a circulator heater be provided for this school at a cost of about $36.00 (I have again looked up the price and find that the plain steel type only costs this figure) with additional cost for pipe of about $3.50.

I believe that by using this circulating heater much fuel may be saved. If the furnace gives out entirely before receiving your letter I may have to set up this heater, as there is quite a good attendance at this school and I presume you would not want the school to be closed on account of the heating system. I know it will save money by installing such a heater as I have mentioned instead of the furnace. The weather here now in intensely cold.

Memorandum

INSPECTION OF BURNT CHURCH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Date of inspection - September 8, 1946.

Teachers - Miss Robichaud and Miss Allain whose qualifications and experience are on file.

School - This was formerly a one-room school building to which a second classroom has been added. On the whole the classrooms are quite satisfactory. The building has been newly painted inside and out.

Both these teachers are capable and interested in their work. Miss Allain is the senior teacher and knows her job well. The children should improve under her teaching. Miss Robichaud has the junior grades and her experience has made her a capable primary teacher. She may be willing to transfer to a school in Western Canada.

Recommendations

1. The provision of a water cooler, cups and coat-hooks.
2. The provision of a sewing machine for the senior room.
3. The provision of blackboards in the junior room.
4. The installation of hydro now on the reserve.

Teacherage -

This is in a separate building and has recently been lined with gyproc and painted. The teachers are quite satisfied with their quarters, particularly as they have now a new stove.

Summary -

This is a two-room school in capable hands and the children should progress well. Both buildings will serve for some time.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

I visited the Burnt Church Indian Day School on the 15th instant. The school building is on a cement foundation, is in good condition, and except for a few minor repairs will be satisfactory during the coming winter.

Both Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, and the local Indian Agent, Mr. Hudson, strongly recommend that, in order to retain the services of teachers at this school, it is necessary that provision be made for the erection of a residence to accommodate two teachers. I would recommend that arrangements be made to have this building erected next summer on the present school site. This is one of the largest reserves in New Brunswick, and it has always been difficult to obtain satisfactory teachers owing to the lack of proper boarding accommodation. This reserve and the Big Cove reserve will be the two most important reserves in New Brunswick, as the Indians from the other reserves are gradually moving to these reserves. A combined school with living quarters is in course of erection at Big Cove, and, when the teachers are installed, this will solve the question of proper school facilities at this reserve. The same arrangement should be undertaken at Burnt Church, where it is necessary that a married teacher or two single teachers be secured. It is considered that a suitable residence could be built at Burnt Church at a cost of approximately $3,000.

At the time the contract is let for the erection of this building, steps should also be taken to make a few alterations and repairs to the school building. The partition at the rear, between the classroom and sewing room, should be removed. This would provide ample seating accommodation for all the children who would attend. The inside walls above the wainscoting should be sheeted. New steps at both entrances should be built. When the contract is let for the building of the residence, it should include the above repairs to the school building.
MEMORANDUM

HON. CHARLES STEWART.

On the Burnt Church Reserve, Province of New Brunswick, it has become difficult to obtain satisfactory teachers owing to the lack of accommodation and boarding facilities. Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Schools for the Province, and Mr. Agent Hudson, Richibucto, have urged the necessity for the erection of a teachers' residence, with accommodation for two teachers.

The Burnt Church Reserve contains a larger population than any other of the Reserves in New Brunswick. There are 40 children of school age. The Indians from other Reserves in the province are gradually moving to this, and the Reserve at Big Cove. It is intended when a residence is provided to secure a married man as teacher and his wife who would assist him and perform certain field matron's duties, or two female teachers - one to perform duties in the classroom and the other to assist and carry on field matron work on the Reserve.

It is proposed to erect a building of the bungalow type, on the same plan as was provided in 1919 for the Red Bank Reserve, the work to be done by day labour, under a competent foreman, the Indian Agent to arrange for the purchase of the material and for the labour required. A plan of the building will be prepared by our Architects and forwarded for the guidance of the Agent, who will oversee the work. Besides the erection of the residence, it is proposed to undertake certain repairs to the school building. The inside walls of the classroom are to be sheeted above the wainscoting, and a partition between the classroom and sewing room is to be removed in order to provide more accommodation. New steps are to be built at the entrance. It is estimated that the cost of putting up the residence for the teacher and the repairs to the school would be approximately $1200. An item has been included in the estimates for the current fiscal year to provide for this expenditure.

I would request your approval for the necessary authority to undertake the above mentioned building operations, the Agent to undertake the work by day labour and to arrange for the purchase of all materials and oversee the work, and that the sum of $1200 be allowed to meet the expenditure.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the building of a teachers residence at the Burnt Church Indian Reserve: I would say that if 18 feet could be added to the length of this building, to be used for Domestic Science class room; the building would then be large enough, but would be better if there was a small sitting room in addition to the bedroom and kitchen.

I have drawn a pencil line on the blue print where I would suggest that the extension be made.

Ottawa, Sept. 18, 1924.

Sir:

With reference to the building of a teachers' residence on the Burnt Church Indian Reserve, I beg to advise you that the Department approves of you proceeding with the erection of a residence by day labour.

I am enclosing herewith blue print copies of the plans, similar to the ones sent you recently, and the building should be built in accordance with these plans with the addition of ten feet on the end in order to provide a sitting room. It is not thought necessary at present to make provision for a domestic science room.

I am also sending you a specification which will be of assistance to you in the purchasing of materials and time sheets on which to keep your labour. Before purchasing the materials you should obtain competitive prices and make the purchase to the best advantage from the firm quoting the lowest price, and when submitting vouchers to the Department for payment a memo should be attached showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. The time sheets should be kept for all labour employed on the building and forwarded to the Department in duplicate. An accountable cheque for payment of labour will be sent to you on application.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant, asking what would be the cost of completing the teachers' residence at the Burnt Church Indian Reserve, I would say that I have to purchase about $50.00 worth of lumber to finish the interior of the building, this together with the cost of labour to complete it would be about $200.00. But this would not include the cost of painting. And as it is entirely too cold at this season of the year to paint I have not yet got any figures on the cost of painting this building. But would say that it is likely to be about $250.00.

Sir I have not done anything at the work since December 20th, when the exterior of the building was completed. I intended to go on with the work this week, but will now wait until I again hear from you. The reason for the delay is that I could not get a carpenter since the Christmas holiday.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

The Secretary

Ottawa, February 5th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, stating the cost required to complete the teachers' residence on the Burnt Church Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure to the amount of approximately $250 in the purchase of the lumber required to finish the interior of the building and in payment of the labour required. I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have the interior of this building completed as soon as weather conditions permit. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed, and a certified account, in duplicate, should also be forwarded covering the cost of the lumber required.

Regarding the painting of this building, I beg to say that this can stand over until next spring. You should bring the matter to the attention of the Department in due time, giving an estimate of the cost of the material and labour required in the painting, and, if it is decided to authorize the work, it can be undertaken during the summer holidays. We have no funds available at the present time to carry out this painting. It is desired, however, to have the building operations finished as soon as you can arrange to have the work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

General Correspondence

Eel Ground School
Dear Sir,

We would like to call your attention to the school department in our district of Elk ground. We have in Elk ground sixty-five children, that ought to attend school, and are deprived of Education from the very fact of not having clothing sufficient to attend school or not having fit footwear. And a great many too hungry to attend school. The average attendance of our school is only thirty scholars. You will give this matter your earliest attention. It would be well to have the town employed teaching that number, as it is teaching eight of a number. What is life without Education?

Another matter I would wish to call attention to, in reference to our Church. The Lieutenant has refused to allow the usual salary, that is usually given yearly, which he claims he is duty bound to do. As for the people that attend Church they are really too poor to pay anything toward the support of the Church. And we demand of you to attend to this matter above all others. The Indians is not like the White man he is barred out from making money and therefore he is unable to give anything to the support of the Church.

Another matter I would call your attention to, which is the principal thing for the welfare of the Indians. And that is...

There has been a small yearly sum of one hundred and seventy-five dollars distributed amongst sixty-six settlers you can gather from this how much farming there is done. What a chance the poor Indians have to live, when he is limited to such a small quantity of seed, they have the finest tracts of land in the country and they only want the seed to sow.

There is also another matter that I would like to bring your attention to. And that is the poor old people of Poor Town. Sir:

Father Duffy recommending the appointment of Miss Lucy Walsh.

In reply I beg to refer you to my letter of the 20th ultimo, in which I was informed that a teacher, to be eligible for the appointment in question, should hold a certificate equal to that of the third class issued in other provinces. As none of the applicants whose names have been submitted up to the present time appear to be so qualified, it would be well if you could obtain applications from others.

With reference to Father Duffy's objection to a Protestant being appointed to the position, I may say that the Department has no preference in this matter one way or the other, and as religious teaching is not a part of the school curriculum, it is not considered a matter of any consequence whether the teacher be a Roman Catholic or a Protestant unless the Indians have a decided preference.

Your obedient servant,
